ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Economic models analyzing exchange rates in short and long run.
Understanding factors relating to exchange rates and trade balance.
Fixed and floating exchange rate regimes and currency crisis.

I learned about the international relationship between money and it's interaction with monetary policy and cross border currency exchange. It was a little esoteric at times but I enjoyed it in a weird way. Learned how to analyze countries like businesses.

I learned about how trade works and how different countries account for trade. I also learned about how exchange rates are linked with trade, GDP, inflation, etc. Very helpful class in understanding macroeconomics and how trade affects different countries' economies and balance of payment.
I learned so much about the interaction of countries and how exchange rate regimes effect a country.
learn about international trade and various exchange rate regimes

I gained an immense amount of knowledge and skills from this course: from understanding/analyzing the sustainability of multinational profits funding consistent trade deficits; to models explaining the intricate links between money supply, interest rates, and exchange rates; to the history of the gold standard and Bretton Woods; to the troubles underlying developing countries such as the tradeoff between the stability afforded by fixed exchange rate regimes and potential for currency depreciation crises to occur.
Models in international finance (exchange rate, money market, output) and a bit about history of international finance and the balance of payments.
I learned the about fundamental macroeconomic concepts of international finance, centering on exchange rates and monetary policy.
Best macro Econ class here at Yale, hands-down. You'll regret it if you don't take it.
Deeper knowledge on macroeconomics and how international financial systems interact.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great economic models and frameworks to understand currencies and macro trends.
Would be great if there can be a guest speaker (e.g. currency trader, marco investor, professional economist).
Would be great if current events can be added to make content more relevant.

Strengths: Consistent 

Weaknesses: Sometimes a little dry with the content delivery. Found it hard to stay engaged during class because it was so econ-like. Didn't quite follow the social narratives that informed on international finance

Strengths: the class builds step by step toward a complete model for international finance. The class also follows the book pretty closely, everything is very logical. I really like the pace of the class. We also have a good amount of homework practice to test our knowledge. Prof Fieler's office hours are very helpful.
No weaknesses

Strengths: very clear lecture notes, clear reference to the textbook, homework is very useful practice and graded more on completion so it is not stressful while also being helpful for learning, exams are fair and stem from the homework and the practice problems given

Weaknesses: none

Strengths: expectations are pretty clear and it's not too demanding, and for a boring topic the class is relatively interesting

Weaknesses: lecture was sometimes monotonous. Also it was always hard to hear and see.
The first part of the occurs on the current account was not particularly useful in my opinion, but the exchange rate and money market analyses seemed very practical.

This course is well-organized, and the main strength is definitely Professor Fielershe was clearly very knowledgeable about the topic and always willing to help answer questions during office hours. Her care for students definitely showed throughout the semester! Main weakness is just the early time slot in Watson, which I think made lectures a little less engaging in general.
Best macro Econ class here at Yale, hands-down. You'll regret it if you don't take it.

Strengths -  well organized lectures and clear explanations, 3 midterm exam format was also helpful by reducing the pressure of a final exam 
Weakness - courseload was very heavy due to the usage of the textbook. lectures often did not cover the entire chapter

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are interested in currencies, trade, and currency crisis, it is a great course to take. If you are interested in the Euro and its advantages and disadvantages, also a great course to take. Pay attention in lectures and you can get a lot out of it.
Yes, if you have an interest and background in economics. Otherwise, you might be doing too much

YES!  If you're interested in trade, exchange rates, or just how countries connect to each other economically, this is a great class to help you understand these. Even though this class is at 9 am, I'm so excited when I go to class and ready to learn, because I know Prof Fieler has so much to offer and teach us.
Yes! The professor is so great and truly wants you to learn!
Yes interesting enough and light workload. 3 1 hour exams and weekly psets.

Yes, definitely. This is a great senior seminar that is engaging, interesting, and not that stressfulProf. Fieler really wants you to understand and enjoy the material, and she does a great job at achieving both of those ends.
Yes. You get a pretty solid foundation in international finance, it's appropriately challenging but not super hard, and it's relatively interesting.
Highly recommend this course. One of the most engaging Economics courses Ive taken at Yale.
Yes, probably the best econ senior course overall, in terms of content, course load, and grading
Yes!  It provides fundamental, practical macroeconomic knowledge which is essential to being a good consumer of economic news and functioning well in that space.

Yeah I wouldthis is a straightforward Econ senior seminar taught by a good professor. Like a lot of other Econ classes though, this class is fairly theory-heavy, but there are some lectures devoted to more real-world events involving international trade / finance towards the end of the semester, which I found interesting. Not too demanding in terms of work either, other than the 3 exams, which account for most of the grade. Overall, if youre looking for a solid credit in the Econ major where the course expectations are clearly defined, I would take a look at this class!
Best macro Econ class here at Yale, hands-down. You'll regret it if you don't take it.
Absolutely yes !
Yes, it builds on fundamental macroeconomics knowledge and provides very key insight into elements we interact with frequently (e.g. exchange rates)
